podcast_summary: In this episode of the Planet Money podcast from NPR, host Sarah Gonzalez explores why Americans have significantly less guaranteed paid vacation compared to other countries. She interviews economists and labor historians to understand why the US has never prioritized guaranteed paid vacation and why Americans often don't take all the vacation days they are given. She discusses various theories, including the influence of unions, the Protestant work ethic, and the role of political will. The episode stresses the importance of discussing and challenging the cultural norms around vacation in order to promote change.
podcast_highlights:
Chapter 1: European Attitude Towards Work

- Europeans have a different relationship with work, especially in the summer.
- In many European countries, businesses are completely closed during the summer and workers are guaranteed paid vacation.

Timestamp: 2:11-4:15

Chapter 2: Lack of Paid Vacation in the US

- The US is the only rich country that does not guarantee paid vacation by law.
- In 2018, US workers left 768 million days of earned vacation on the table, forfeiting about $65 billion in vacation benefits.

Timestamp: 5:13-8:17

Chapter 3: Historical Context of Vacation

- European countries pushed for vacation in the 1920s and 1930s, asking their federal governments for policies.
- The US did not prioritize vacation as a right during that time. Unions also drew a line at vacation.

Timestamp: 12:09-14:00

Chapter 4: Work Ethic and Perception of Leisure

- The Protestant work ethic argument does not fully explain the difference between the US and Europe.
- Europeans are not necessarily born valuing leisure more than Americans.

Timestamp: 15:20-16:51

Chapter 5: Business Influence and Political Will

- After the 1930s, businesses regained power and did not want the federal government to mandate worker benefits.
- Guaranteeing paid vacation is a political issue that requires political will to change.

Timestamp: 22:40-24:15

Chapter 6: Changing the Culture

- Talking about vacation and questioning why the US does not guarantee it can help change the culture.
- Encouraging bosses and workers to take more vacation can reduce guilt and make it more acceptable.

Timestamp: 26:38-28:36
